*Called tool*: context7 - resolve-library-id: Resolves a package/product name to a Context7-compatible library ID and returns a list of matching libraries.

You MUST call this function before 'get-library-docs' to obtain a valid Context7-compatible library ID UNLESS the user explicitly provides a library ID in the format '/org/project' or '/org/project/version' in their query.

Selection Process:
1. Analyze the query to understand what library/package the user is looking for
2. Return the most relevant match based on:
- Name similarity to the query (exact matches prioritized)
- Description relevance to the query's intent
- Documentation coverage (prioritize libraries with higher Code Snippet counts)
- Source reputation (consider libraries with High or Medium reputation more authoritative)
- Benchmark Score: Quality indicator (100 is the highest score)

Response Format:
- Return the selected library ID in a clearly marked section
- Provide a brief explanation for why this library was chosen
- If multiple good matches exist, acknowledge this but proceed with the most relevant one
- If no good matches exist, clearly state this and suggest query refinements

For ambiguous queries, request clarification before proceeding with a best-guess match.

  * libraryName: radzen blazor

Available Libraries:

Each result includes:
- Library ID: Context7-compatible identifier (format: /org/project)
- Name: Library or package name
- Description: Short summary

- Source Reputation: Authority indicator (High, Medium, Low, or Unknown)
- Benchmark Score: Quality indicator (100 is the highest score)
- Versions: List of versions if available. Use one of those versions if the user provides a version in their query. The format of the version is /org/project/version.

For best results, select libraries based on name match, source reputation, snippet coverage, benchmark score, and relevance to your use case.

Source: https://blazor.radzen.com/docs/api/Radzen.Blazor

*Result*:
### Displaying Alert and Confirm Dialogs with DialogService

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Shows how to use Radzen's DialogService to display standard alert and confirm dialogs. These methods provide a simple way to get user acknowledgment or confirmation. Customizable options include button text, dialog title, and size.

```csharp
@inject DialogService DialogService

<RadzenButton Text="Show Alert" Click="@ShowAlert" />
<RadzenButton Text="Show Confirm" Click="@ShowConfirm" />

@code {
    async Task ShowAlert()
    {
        await DialogService.Alert(
            "Operation completed successfully!",
            "Success",
            new AlertOptions {
                OkButtonText = "Got it",
                Width = "400px"
            }
        );
    }

    async Task ShowConfirm()
    {
        bool? result = await DialogService.Confirm(
            "Are you sure you want to delete this record?",
            "Confirm Delete",
            new ConfirmOptions {
                OkButtonText = "Delete",
                CancelButtonText = "Keep",
                Width = "450px"
            }
        );

        if (result == true)
        {
            // User confirmed - proceed with deletion
            Console.WriteLine("Record deleted");
        }
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Creating Inline Content Dialogs with DialogService

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Illustrates how to create dialogs with inline Blazor content using RenderFragment with Radzen's DialogService. This approach is useful for simple dialogs or confirmations without needing a separate component file. It supports closing the dialog with a return value and refreshing dialog content.

```csharp
@inject DialogService DialogService

<RadzenButton Text="Show Inline Dialog" Click="@ShowInlineDialog" />

@code {
    int orderID = 10248;

    async Task ShowInlineDialog()
    {
        var result = await DialogService.OpenAsync("Confirm Order", ds =>
            @<RadzenStack Gap="1.5rem">
                <p>Confirm Order ID <b>@orderID</b>?</p>
                <RadzenStack Orientation="Orientation.Horizontal" Gap="0.5rem">
                    <RadzenButton Text="Ok" Click="() => ds.Close(true)" />
                    <RadzenButton Text="Cancel" Click="() => ds.Close(false)"
                                  ButtonStyle="ButtonStyle.Light" />
                    <RadzenButton Text="Refresh"
                                  Click="(() => { orderID = 10249; ds.Refresh(); })"
                                  ButtonStyle="ButtonStyle.Light" />
                </RadzenStack>
            </RadzenStack>
        );

        Console.WriteLine($"Dialog result: {result}");
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Opening Custom Component Dialogs with DialogService

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Demonstrates how to open a modal dialog using a custom Blazor component with Radzen's DialogService. This method allows passing parameters to the custom component and configuring dialog options like size, resizability, and draggable behavior. The result from the dialog can be asynchronously awaited.

```csharp
@page "/example"
@inject DialogService DialogService

<RadzenButton Text="Open Dialog" Click="@ShowDialog" />

@code {
    async Task ShowDialog()
    {
        var result = await DialogService.OpenAsync<MyCustomComponent>(
            "Dialog Title",
            new Dictionary<string, object> {
                { "Parameter1", "value1" },
                { "Parameter2", 42 }
            },
            new DialogOptions {
                Width = "700px",
                Height = "500px",
                Resizable = true,
                Draggable = true
            }
        );

        if (result != null)
        {
            Console.WriteLine($"Dialog closed with result: {result}");
        }
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Include Radzen.Blazor.js for .NET 8

Source: https://github.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/blob/master/getting-started.md

Include the Radzen.Blazor.js script in your `App.razor` file for .NET 8 applications. This script is essential for the functionality of Radzen Blazor components. The version is dynamically determined.

```html
<script src="_content/Radzen.Blazor/Radzen.Blazor.js?v=@(typeof(Radzen.Colors).Assembly.GetName().Version)"></script>
```

--------------------------------

### NotificationService: Display Toast Notifications (C#)

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Demonstrates how to display toast notifications with different severity levels (Success, Error, Warning, Info) and durations using Radzen's NotificationService. Requires RadzenComponents to be present in the layout. It shows both constructor-based and named-argument based notification message creation.

```csharp
@inject NotificationService NotificationService

<RadzenButton Text="Success" Click="@ShowSuccess" />
<RadzenButton Text="Error" Click="@ShowError" />
<RadzenButton Text="Warning" Click="@ShowWarning" />
<RadzenButton Text="Info" Click="@ShowInfo" />

@code {
    void ShowSuccess()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(new NotificationMessage
        {
            Severity = NotificationSeverity.Success,
            Summary = "Success",
            Detail = "Your changes have been saved successfully.",
            Duration = 4000
        });
    }

    void ShowError()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(
            severity: NotificationSeverity.Error,
            summary: "Error Occurred",
            detail: "Failed to save changes. Please try again.",
            duration: 5000
        );
    }

    void ShowWarning()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(new NotificationMessage
        {
            Severity = NotificationSeverity.Warning,
            Summary = "Warning",
            Detail = "This action cannot be undone.",
            Duration = 3000,
            ShowProgress = true
        });
    }

    void ShowInfo()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(
            NotificationSeverity.Info,
            "Information",
            "New updates are available."
        );
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### NotificationService: Interactive Notifications with Custom Content (C#)

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Shows how to create interactive toast notifications using Radzen's NotificationService that support click handlers, custom payloads, and custom content via RenderFragments. The example demonstrates setting a duration of 0 for non-auto-closing notifications, disabling click-to-close, and defining custom SummaryContent and DetailContent.

```csharp
@inject NotificationService NotificationService

<RadzenButton Text="Show Interactive Notification" Click="@ShowInteractive" />

@code {
    void ShowInteractive()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(new NotificationMessage
        {
            Severity = NotificationSeverity.Info,
            Summary = "New Message",
            Detail = "Click to view details",
            Duration = 0, // Don't auto-close
            CloseOnClick = false,
            Payload = new { MessageId = 123 },
            Click = message =>
            {
                var payload = message.Payload as dynamic;
                Console.WriteLine($"Opening message: {payload.MessageId}");
            },
            Close = message =>
            {
                Console.WriteLine("Notification closed");
            },
            SummaryContent = ns => @<b style="color: #0078d4;">üìß New Email</b>,
            DetailContent = ns => @<div>
                <p>From: john@example.com</p>
                <RadzenButton Text="View" Size="ButtonSize.Small" />
            </div>
        });
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### ContextMenuService: Custom Context Menus (C#)

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Illustrates how to use Radzen's ContextMenuService to display custom context menus at the position of a mouse click. The example defines a list of `ContextMenuItem` objects with text, values, icons, and a click handler that logs the selected item's value and closes the menu. It also shows how to disable menu items.

```csharp
@inject ContextMenuService ContextMenuService

<RadzenButton Text="Show Context Menu"
              ContextMenu="@(args => ShowContextMenu(args))" />

@code {
    void ShowContextMenu(MouseEventArgs args)
    {
        ContextMenuService.Open(args, new List<ContextMenuItem>
        {
            new ContextMenuItem
            {
                Text = "Edit",
                Value = "edit",
                Icon = "edit"
            },
            new ContextMenuItem
            {
                Text = "Delete",
                Value = "delete",
                Icon = "delete",
                IconColor = "red"
            },
            new ContextMenuItem
            {
                Text = "Disabled",
                Value = "disabled",
                Disabled = true
            }
        },
        click: args =>
        {
            Console.WriteLine($"Menu item clicked: {args.Value}");
            ContextMenuService.Close();
        });
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Implement Custom Context Menu with Radzen Blazor ContextMenuService

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Demonstrates how to use Radzen Blazor's ContextMenuService to display a custom context menu with any Blazor content, such as a RadzenMenu, using a RenderFragment. It includes event handling for menu item clicks and closing the menu.

```csharp
@inject ContextMenuService ContextMenuService

<div @oncontextmenu="@ShowCustomContextMenu"
     @oncontextmenu:preventDefault="true"
     style="border: 1px solid #ccc; padding: 20px;">
    Right-click here
</div>

@code {
    void ShowCustomContextMenu(MouseEventArgs args)
    {
        ContextMenuService.Open(args, ds =>
            @<RadzenMenu Click="OnMenuItemClick">
                <RadzenMenuItem Text="Item 1" Value="1" />
                <RadzenMenuItem Text="Item 2" Value="2" />
                <RadzenMenuItem Text="More Items" Value="3">
                    <RadzenMenuItem Text="Sub Item 1" Value="4" />
                    <RadzenMenuItem Text="Sub Item 2" Value="5" />
                </RadzenMenuItem>
            </RadzenMenu>
        );
    }

    void OnMenuItemClick(MenuItemEventArgs args)
    {
        Console.WriteLine($"Menu item with Value={args.Value} clicked");
        ContextMenuService.Close();
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Configure RadzenComponents for .NET 7 & .NET 6

Source: https://github.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/blob/master/getting-started.md

For .NET 7 and .NET 6 applications, include the `<RadzenComponents />` tag in your `MainLayout.razor` file. This setup is required for Radzen dialogs, context menus, tooltips, and notifications.

```html
<RadzenComponents />
```

--------------------------------

### Configure RadzenComponents for .NET 8

Source: https://github.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/blob/master/getting-started.md

In .NET 8, add the `<RadzenComponents @rendermode=InteractiveAuto />` tag to your `MainLayout.razor` file. This is necessary for interactive components like dialogs and tooltips, and requires an interactive render mode.

```html
<RadzenComponents @rendermode=InteractiveAuto />
```

I need to understand better how Radzen dialogs work and if there's a way to update the title dynamically. Let me look at the Radzen source code or additional documentation.

Looking at the existing code, the dialog is opened with:
```csharp
await DialogService.OpenAsync<TestSequenceEditor>("Test Sequence Editor", ...)
```

The title "Test Sequence Editor" is passed statically. Looking at the photo, the user wants the title to be something like "{filename}.sqc - Test Sequence Editor" in the dialog header.

Based on Radzen Blazor's capabilities, there are a few approaches:
1. Use `DialogService.Title` property to dynamically change the title after the dialog is opened
2. Use `DialogService.Refresh()` to update the dialog content (but this may not update the title)
3. Pass a delegate or use `ds.Close()` and reopen with a new title (not ideal)

Let me search for `DialogService.Title` specifically in the Radzen API.</details></think>

---

Based on my research, I understand what you need. Looking at the photo, you want to move the filename display from inside the table header to the **Radzen Dialog title bar**, similar to how it appears in the Siemens HMI interface showing something like `024COMFNTE.sqc - Test Sequence Editor`.

Currently, `TestSequenceEditor` is opened as a Radzen Dialog with a static title "Test Sequence Editor". To show the filename in the dialog title, we need to:

1. Update the dialog title dynamically when a file is opened/created using `DialogService.Title` property
2. Remove the filename display from the table header area

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Based on the search results, it looks like Radzen DialogService doesn't support dynamically changing the title after the dialog is opened. The title is set when opening the dialog.

However, I recall that Radzen does have a way to update the dialog title through `DialogService.Options`. Let me check the Radzen source code or API for the correct approach.

Actually, looking at this more carefully, I think Radzen `DialogService` might have:
- `Options` property that has a `Title` property
- OR we could close and reopen the dialog (not ideal)

Let me try a different approach - checking if `DialogService.Options` exists and has a Title property.</details></think>

### Displaying Alert and Confirm Dialogs with DialogService

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Shows how to use Radzen's DialogService to display standard alert and confirm dialogs. These methods provide a simple way to get user acknowledgment or confirmation. Customizable options include button text, dialog title, and size.

```csharp
@inject DialogService DialogService

<RadzenButton Text="Show Alert" Click="@ShowAlert" />
<RadzenButton Text="Show Confirm" Click="@ShowConfirm" />

@code {
    async Task ShowAlert()
    {
        await DialogService.Alert(
            "Operation completed successfully!",
            "Success",
            new AlertOptions {
                OkButtonText = "Got it",
                Width = "400px"
            }
        );
    }

    async Task ShowConfirm()
    {
        bool? result = await DialogService.Confirm(
            "Are you sure you want to delete this record?",
            "Confirm Delete",
            new ConfirmOptions {
                OkButtonText = "Delete",
                CancelButtonText = "Keep",
                Width = "450px"
            }
        );

        if (result == true)
        {
            // User confirmed - proceed with deletion
            Console.WriteLine("Record deleted");
        }
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Creating Inline Content Dialogs with DialogService

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Illustrates how to create dialogs with inline Blazor content using RenderFragment with Radzen's DialogService. This approach is useful for simple dialogs or confirmations without needing a separate component file. It supports closing the dialog with a return value and refreshing dialog content.

```csharp
@inject DialogService DialogService

<RadzenButton Text="Show Inline Dialog" Click="@ShowInlineDialog" />

@code {
    int orderID = 10248;

    async Task ShowInlineDialog()
    {
        var result = await DialogService.OpenAsync("Confirm Order", ds =>
            @<RadzenStack Gap="1.5rem">
                <p>Confirm Order ID <b>@orderID</b>?</p>
                <RadzenStack Orientation="Orientation.Horizontal" Gap="0.5rem">
                    <RadzenButton Text="Ok" Click="() => ds.Close(true)" />
                    <RadzenButton Text="Cancel" Click="() => ds.Close(false)"
                                  ButtonStyle="ButtonStyle.Light" />
                    <RadzenButton Text="Refresh"
                                  Click="(() => { orderID = 10249; ds.Refresh(); })"
                                  ButtonStyle="ButtonStyle.Light" />
                </RadzenStack>
            </RadzenStack>
        );

        Console.WriteLine($"Dialog result: {result}");
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Opening Custom Component Dialogs with DialogService

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Demonstrates how to open a modal dialog using a custom Blazor component with Radzen's DialogService. This method allows passing parameters to the custom component and configuring dialog options like size, resizability, and draggable behavior. The result from the dialog can be asynchronously awaited.

```csharp
@page "/example"
@inject DialogService DialogService

<RadzenButton Text="Open Dialog" Click="@ShowDialog" />

@code {
    async Task ShowDialog()
    {
        var result = await DialogService.OpenAsync<MyCustomComponent>(
            "Dialog Title",
            new Dictionary<string, object> {
                { "Parameter1", "value1" },
                { "Parameter2", 42 }
            },
            new DialogOptions {
                Width = "700px",
                Height = "500px",
                Resizable = true,
                Draggable = true
            }
        );

        if (result != null)
        {
            Console.WriteLine($"Dialog closed with result: {result}");
        }
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### NotificationService: Interactive Notifications with Custom Content (C#)

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Shows how to create interactive toast notifications using Radzen's NotificationService that support click handlers, custom payloads, and custom content via RenderFragments. The example demonstrates setting a duration of 0 for non-auto-closing notifications, disabling click-to-close, and defining custom SummaryContent and DetailContent.

```csharp
@inject NotificationService NotificationService

<RadzenButton Text="Show Interactive Notification" Click="@ShowInteractive" />

@code {
    void ShowInteractive()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(new NotificationMessage
        {
            Severity = NotificationSeverity.Info,
            Summary = "New Message",
            Detail = "Click to view details",
            Duration = 0, // Don't auto-close
            CloseOnClick = false,
            Payload = new { MessageId = 123 },
            Click = message =>
            {
                var payload = message.Payload as dynamic;
                Console.WriteLine($"Opening message: {payload.MessageId}");
            },
            Close = message =>
            {
                Console.WriteLine("Notification closed");
            },
            SummaryContent = ns => @<b style="color: #0078d4;">üìß New Email</b>,
            DetailContent = ns => @<div>
                <p>From: john@example.com</p>
                <RadzenButton Text="View" Size="ButtonSize.Small" />
            </div>
        });
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### NotificationService: Display Toast Notifications (C#)

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Demonstrates how to display toast notifications with different severity levels (Success, Error, Warning, Info) and durations using Radzen's NotificationService. Requires RadzenComponents to be present in the layout. It shows both constructor-based and named-argument based notification message creation.

```csharp
@inject NotificationService NotificationService

<RadzenButton Text="Success" Click="@ShowSuccess" />
<RadzenButton Text="Error" Click="@ShowError" />
<RadzenButton Text="Warning" Click="@ShowWarning" />
<RadzenButton Text="Info" Click="@ShowInfo" />

@code {
    void ShowSuccess()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(new NotificationMessage
        {
            Severity = NotificationSeverity.Success,
            Summary = "Success",
            Detail = "Your changes have been saved successfully.",
            Duration = 4000
        });
    }

    void ShowError()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(
            severity: NotificationSeverity.Error,
            summary: "Error Occurred",
            detail: "Failed to save changes. Please try again.",
            duration: 5000
        );
    }

    void ShowWarning()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(new NotificationMessage
        {
            Severity = NotificationSeverity.Warning,
            Summary = "Warning",
            Detail = "This action cannot be undone.",
            Duration = 3000,
            ShowProgress = true
        });
    }

    void ShowInfo()
    {
        NotificationService.Notify(
            NotificationSeverity.Info,
            "Information",
            "New updates are available."
        );
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### ContextMenuService: Custom Context Menus (C#)

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Illustrates how to use Radzen's ContextMenuService to display custom context menus at the position of a mouse click. The example defines a list of `ContextMenuItem` objects with text, values, icons, and a click handler that logs the selected item's value and closes the menu. It also shows how to disable menu items.

```csharp
@inject ContextMenuService ContextMenuService

<RadzenButton Text="Show Context Menu"
              ContextMenu="@(args => ShowContextMenu(args))" />

@code {
    void ShowContextMenu(MouseEventArgs args)
    {
        ContextMenuService.Open(args, new List<ContextMenuItem>
        {
            new ContextMenuItem
            {
                Text = "Edit",
                Value = "edit",
                Icon = "edit"
            },
            new ContextMenuItem
            {
                Text = "Delete",
                Value = "delete",
                Icon = "delete",
                IconColor = "red"
            },
            new ContextMenuItem
            {
                Text = "Disabled",
                Value = "disabled",
                Disabled = true
            }
        },
        click: args =>
        {
            Console.WriteLine($"Menu item clicked: {args.Value}");
            ContextMenuService.Close();
        });
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Implement Custom Context Menu with Radzen Blazor ContextMenuService

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

Demonstrates how to use Radzen Blazor's ContextMenuService to display a custom context menu with any Blazor content, such as a RadzenMenu, using a RenderFragment. It includes event handling for menu item clicks and closing the menu.

```csharp
@inject ContextMenuService ContextMenuService

<div @oncontextmenu="@ShowCustomContextMenu"
     @oncontextmenu:preventDefault="true"
     style="border: 1px solid #ccc; padding: 20px;">
    Right-click here
</div>

@code {
    void ShowCustomContextMenu(MouseEventArgs args)
    {
        ContextMenuService.Open(args, ds =>
            @<RadzenMenu Click="OnMenuItemClick">
                <RadzenMenuItem Text="Item 1" Value="1" />
                <RadzenMenuItem Text="Item 2" Value="2" />
                <RadzenMenuItem Text="More Items" Value="3">
                    <RadzenMenuItem Text="Sub Item 1" Value="4" />
                    <RadzenMenuItem Text="Sub Item 2" Value="5" />
                </RadzenMenuItem>
            </RadzenMenu>
        );
    }

    void OnMenuItemClick(MenuItemEventArgs args)
    {
        Console.WriteLine($"Menu item with Value={args.Value} clicked");
        ContextMenuService.Close();
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

### Configure RadzenComponents for .NET 8

Source: https://github.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/blob/master/getting-started.md

In .NET 8, add the `<RadzenComponents @rendermode=InteractiveAuto />` tag to your `MainLayout.razor` file. This is necessary for interactive components like dialogs and tooltips, and requires an interactive render mode.

```html
<RadzenComponents @rendermode=InteractiveAuto />
```

--------------------------------

### Configure RadzenComponents for .NET 7 & .NET 6

Source: https://github.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/blob/master/getting-started.md

For .NET 7 and .NET 6 applications, include the `<RadzenComponents />` tag in your `MainLayout.razor` file. This setup is required for Radzen dialogs, context menus, tooltips, and notifications.

```html
<RadzenComponents />
```

--------------------------------

### Configure RadzenDataGrid with Filtering and Sorting in Blazor

Source: https://context7.com/radzenhq/radzen-blazor/llms.txt

This Razor component demonstrates how to configure RadzenDataGrid with advanced filtering and sorting capabilities. It includes examples of custom filter templates for text and dropdowns, inline editing buttons, and data binding. Dependencies include Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.

```razor
@using Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore

<RadzenDataGrid @ref="grid"
                Data="@employees"
                TItem="Employee"
                AllowFiltering="true"
                AllowSorting="true"
                AllowPaging="true"
                PageSize="10"
                FilterMode="FilterMode.Advanced"
                AllowColumnResize="true"
                ColumnWidth="200px"
                FilterCaseSensitivity="FilterCaseSensitivity.CaseInsensitive"
                LogicalFilterOperator="LogicalFilterOperator.Or">
    <Columns>
        <RadzenDataGridColumn Property="@nameof(Employee.EmployeeID)"
                              Title="ID"
                              Width="80px"
                              Frozen="true" />

        <RadzenDataGridColumn Property="@nameof(Employee.FirstName)"
                              Title="First Name"
                              FilterValue="@firstNameFilter">
            <FilterValueTemplate>
                <RadzenTextBox @bind-Value="@firstNameFilter" />
            </FilterValueTemplate>
        </RadzenDataGridColumn>

        <RadzenDataGridColumn Property="@nameof(Employee.LastName)"
                              Title="Last Name" />

        <RadzenDataGridColumn Property="@nameof(Employee.Title)"
                              Title="Job Title"
                              Type="typeof(IEnumerable<string>)"
                              FilterValue="@selectedTitles"
                              FilterOperator="FilterOperator.Contains">
            <FilterValueTemplate>
                <RadzenDropDown @bind-Value="@selectedTitles"
                                Data="@titles"
                                AllowClear="true"
                                Multiple="true" />
            </FilterValueTemplate>
        </RadzenDataGridColumn>

        <RadzenDataGridColumn Property="@nameof(Employee.BirthDate)"
                              Title="Birth Date"
                              FormatString="{0:d}" />

        <RadzenDataGridColumn Title="Actions" Sortable="false" Filterable="false">
            <Template Context="employee">
                <RadzenButton Icon="edit" Size="ButtonSize.Small"
                              Click="@(() => EditEmployee(employee))" />
                <RadzenButton Icon="delete" ButtonStyle="ButtonStyle.Danger"
                              Size="ButtonSize.Small"
                              Click="@(() => DeleteEmployee(employee))" />
            </Template>
        </RadzenDataGridColumn>
    </Columns>
</RadzenDataGrid>

@code {
    RadzenDataGrid<Employee> grid;
    List<Employee> employees;
    string firstNameFilter;
    IEnumerable<string> selectedTitles;
    List<string> titles = new List<string> { "Manager", "Developer", "Designer" };

    protected override async Task OnInitializedAsync()
    {
        employees = await GetEmployees();
    }

    void EditEmployee(Employee employee)
    {
        Console.WriteLine($"Editing {employee.FirstName} {employee.LastName}");
    }

    void DeleteEmployee(Employee employee)
    {
        employees.Remove(employee);
        grid.Reload();
    }
}

```
</details>
</tool-use>

---

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Based on the documentation, I can see that Radzen DialogService's `Refresh()` method exists, but there doesn't seem to be a direct `Title` property on the DialogService.

Looking at the inline dialog example:
```csharp
DialogService.OpenAsync("Confirm Order", ds =>
    @<RadzenStack Gap="1.5rem">
        <RadzenButton Text="Refresh"
                      Click="(() => { orderID = 10249; ds.Refresh(); })"
                      ButtonStyle="ButtonStyle.Light" />
    </RadzenStack>
);
```

The `ds` parameter passed to the RenderFragment is the DialogService instance, and it has a `Refresh()` method that can refresh the dialog content. But the title is passed when opening the dialog.

Looking at the Radzen GitHub source code, I know that DialogService has:
- `Options` property that can contain settings
- But the title might need to be set through `Options.Title`

Let me try using `DialogService.Options.Title` instead.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
It seems like `DialogService.Options` also doesn't exist directly. Let me check the actual Radzen Blazor source code to see what methods/properties are available on DialogService.

Based on my research, the Radzen DialogService appears to work differently. The title is set when opening the dialog, and there's no direct way to change it after the dialog is opened.

However, I have another approach:
1. The dialog component could emit an event that updates the title
2. We could store a reference to the current dialog and use reflection
3. Or we could use JavaScript interop to directly modify the DOM

Actually, looking at Radzen's GitHub repository, I see that DialogService has a method called `UpdateOptions` or similar, but it's not well-documented.

Let me try a different approach - using JavaScript interop to update the dialog title directly in the DOM, which would be simpler and more reliable.

Alternatively, I could check if there's a way to get the current dialog options and modify them.

Let me search for the actual Radzen DialogService API.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Now I have a full picture of the code. Let me analyze it against the .cursorrules:

**Issues found:**

1. **TestSequenceEditor.File.cs (233 lines)** - close to limit but ok
2. **TestSequenceEditor.Save.cs (188 lines)** - ok
3. **TestSequenceEditor.Grid.cs (80 lines)** - ok
4. **TestSequenceEditor.Actions.cs (117 lines)** - ok
5. **TestSequenceEditor.razor.cs (33 lines)** - ok

**Violations of .cursorrules:**

1. **TestSequenceEditor.File.cs line 219-226**: `UpdateDialogTitleAsync` - uses `var` correctly, but `baseName` should use `var` instead of `const string` (wait, actually const is fine for compile-time constants).

Actually looking more carefully:

2. **Multiple try-catch in same logical flow**: This is hard to avoid with the current structure.

3. **NotifySuccessIfNotDisposed and NotifyLoadErrorIfNotDisposed**: These methods are unnecessarily complex - they could be simplified with early return pattern in the caller.

4. **Unused parameter `filePath` in `NotifySuccess`**: The parameter is declared but not really needed since we access `TestSequenceService.CurrentFileName` directly.

5. **TryLoadAndNotify has nested try-catch**: This violates the "one structure per method" rule indirectly.

6. **Empty OnRowSelect method**: This should be removed if not used.

7. **TestSequenceEditor.razor.cs** has properties without blank line before methods - need to check structure.

8. **`var baseName` should be used instead of `const string baseName`** - wait, const is a valid C# pattern. Actually, the rule says "var for all types" - but const string isn't a variable declaration with initialization from another value, it's a compile-time constant. I'll change it to follow the spirit of the rule.


I'll draft a strategic refactoring approach targeting code simplification and rule compliance. The plan will focus on incremental improvements, starting with removing unnecessary code and simplifying complex methods. I'll prioritize cleaning up unused parameters, eliminating redundant methods, and ensuring consistent code structure across files.

The refactoring will proceed through three key phases:
1. Remove unused elements and simplify complex logic
2. Align code with .cursorrules specifications
3. Optimize code structure and improve overall readability

This methodical approach will help streamline the codebase while maintaining its core functionality and intent.</details></think>

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Plan)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user is describing a bug: when they close the sequence editor dialog and reopen it, the Save and Save As buttons are still active even though no file should be loaded.

Looking at the code:

1. In `TestSequenceEditor.razor.cs`:
```csharp
protected override void OnInitialized()
{
    _rows = TestSequenceService.InitializeRows(20, _columnCount);
    _isFileActive = !string.IsNullOrEmpty(TestSequenceService.CurrentFilePath);
}
```

2. The `TestSequenceService` is a scoped service that persists the `CurrentFilePath` and `CurrentFileName` across dialog opens/closes.

3. When the dialog is closed via `Dispose()`, it only sets `_disposed = true` but doesn't clear the `TestSequenceService.CurrentFilePath` and `TestSequenceService.CurrentFileName`.

So the fix should be to clear the service state when the dialog is disposed/closed.

Let me add this to the refactoring plan.</details></think>

---
